an11.118-165.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Eye Consciousness, Etc.

an11.11.blurb: Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.

an11.10.blurb: Possessing various sets of qualities, a mendicant is best among gods and men.

an11.18.blurb: The Buddha is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

an11.30-69.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on the Ear, Etc.

an11.406-453.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Thoughts About Sights, Etc.

an11.4.blurb: Sāriputta teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

an11.502-981.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on the Eye, Etc.

an11.5.blurb: Ānanda teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

an11.214-261.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Feeling Born of Eye Contact, Etc.

an11.8.blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal attention has ceased, but there is still attention. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists.

an11.7.blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists. Ānanda puts the same question to Sāriputta, and gets the same answer.

an11.20.blurb: Sāriputta is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

an11.166-213.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Eye Contact, Etc.

an11.358-405.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Craving For Sights, Etc.

an11.262-309.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Perception of Sights, Etc.

an11.17.blurb: A cowherd with eleven qualities is competent to look after a herd of cattle. Likewise, a mendicant with eleven qualities can grow in the Dhamma.

an11.15.blurb: The meditation on love has eleven benefits.

an11.9.blurb: The Buddha tells Venerable Sandha to meditate like a trained thoroughbred, not like a wild colt. Doing so, they may attain a deep state.

an11.14.blurb: Venerable Subhūti brings the young monk Saddha to meet the Buddha. The Buddha goes on to teach the manifestations of faith.

an11.21.blurb: Sāriputta teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

an11.1.blurb: Good conduct leads to non-regret, to joy, and so on all the way to liberation.

an11.13.blurb: Nandiya the Sakiyan moves to Sāvatthī to be near the Buddha. At the end of the rains, he asks the Buddha’s advice on how to live.

an11.2.blurb: A virtuous person need not make a wish; it is natural for the path to flow on.

an11.310-357.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Intention Regarding Sights, Etc.

an11.19.blurb: The Buddha teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

an11.6.blurb: When a mendicant abuses their fellow monastics, eleven disasters follow.

an11.16.blurb: Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.

an11.12.blurb: Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.

an11.3.blurb: The Buddha teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.

an11.454-501.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Considerations Regarding Sights, Etc.

an.blurb: The “Numbered” or “Numerical” Discourses are usually known as Aṅguttara Nikāya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (“one-up” or “incremental”), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nikāyas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarikāgama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali Aṅguttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarikāgama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.
